Award.AwardTitle: Legendrian graphs, invariants and DNA topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to broaden our understanding of many topological aspects of spatial graphs, and make it possible to answer larger questions about its external three-dimensional space (or three-space) and biological mechanisms. A graph is a set of points called vertices and curves between the points called edges. A spatial graph is a graph that is sitting in three-space. A spatial graph can be very complicated and knotted. Spatial graph theory is a recent field which grew out of knot theory, the study of knotted circles in three-space. In addition to contributing to our understanding of connections between spatial graphs and their surrounding three-space, this project has direct applications to biological questions. Knot theory has become important within the life sciences, in the field of DNA Topology. Most of the DNA that is worked with in laboratories is in small circular molecules that are called plasmids. Circular DNA also appears in nature. Plasmids can naturally be modeled with knots. With every cell division the DNA is copied in a process called replication. This is a complicated process that involves a number of enzymes. After replication the two new plasmids are linked (or catenated) and sometimes knotted. The reason for knotting is not completely understood. In the middle of replication DNA forms the more complicated structures, that of a knotted graph, this is an area of DNA topology that has yet to be investigated by mathematicians. This project will have immediate contributions to our biological understanding of DNA replication.


In particular, the PI will focus on three main projects centering around spatial graphs: First, the PI will study a number of aspects of Legendrian graphs. Central results in contact geometry use Legendrian graphs in their proofs. Thus this opens an exciting new area with great potential. These projects will increase the overall understanding of Legendrian graphs, further increasing their potential to use Legendrian graphs as a tool to understand 3-manifolds, and potentially distinguish contact structures. Second, the PI will develop new invariants and better understand existing invariants of spatial graphs and knots, including graph Floer homology. Third, the PI will begin classification of unknotting number one theta-graphs to understand unknotting in DNA replication intermediates.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to broaden our understanding of many topological aspects of spatial graphs, and make it possible to answer larger questions about its external three-dimensional space (or three-space) and biological mechanisms. A graph is a set of vertices and edges between the vertices. A graph is an abstract object. A spatial graph is the realization of a graph in three-dimensional space.  In a spatial graph the vertices are points and edges are curves between the points.  Spatial graph theory is a natural extension of knot theory, the study of embeddings of simple closed curves in 3-manifolds.  Beyond the mathematical insight gained from studying these complex objects there are further applications outside of mathematics to biology and chemistry. In particular, this project focused on understanding knotting in DNA during replication, understanding Legendrian graphs and developing invariants for spatial graphs. 

Knot theory has become important within the life sciences, in the field of DNA Topology. Most of the DNA that is worked with in laboratories is in small circular molecules that are called plasmids. Circular DNA also appears in nature. Plasmids can naturally be modeled with knots. However, before this project spatial graph theory had not been used in DNA Topology.  With every cell division the DNA is copied in a process called replication. This is a complicated process that involves a number of enzymes. After replication the two new plasmids are linked (or catenated) and sometimes knotted. The reason for knotting is not completely understood. In this project we investigated the knotting that occurs during replication. 

In the middle of replication DNA forms a more complicated structures called a partially replicated DNA molecule. Partially replicated DNA molecules are naturally modeled with a knotted graph, in particular by a knotted theta-curve.  This is the graph with two vertices and three edges between the vertices.  As part of this project we investigated how theta-curves can become knotted and unknotted.  This was then used to narrows the potential replication intermediates to a particular set of theta-curves.  In collaboration with Dorothy Buck and Andrzej Stasiak, the PI examined the mechanism of formation of DNA knots in partially replicated DNA molecules. Our analysis revealed more general and complete model that explains how knotted, twist-like theta-curves can be formed. This also gives additional evidence for the current theorized conformation of the partially replicated DNA molecules.

The remaining portion of the work in this project was focused on pure mathematics.  A recent and deep invariant of knots is Knot Floer homology.  Knot Floer homology has many applications and successes in low-dimensional topology.  A major accomplishment in this project was the definition a Floer homology invariant for spatial graphs. This was done in collaboration with Shelly Harvey.  This was done in a combinatorial fashion using grid diagrams.  This is the foundation to build on our understanding of spatial graphs with Floer homology. 

The final objective of this project was to deepen our understand of Legendrian graphs.  Legendrian graphs are spatial graphs subject to particular rules that are in three-space with additional structure.  More exactly, it is in a contact 3-manifold, which is a 3-manifold together with a plane field that in completely non-integrable.  A Legendrian graph is a spatial graph that is everywhere tangent to the contact planes.  Legendrian graphs naturally appear in several important contexts in contact geometry and are used in the proofs of many central results.
We developed new invariants for Legendrian graphs.  We examined Legedrian simplicity for graphs, and other questions about Legendrian realizability.  This work was in collaboration with Elena Pavelescu and Peter Lambert-Cole. 


Last Modified: 11/03/2019
Modified by: Danielle O'donnol
